maml:description.maml:para: Create a new Nano server image.

This command will create a new Nano server disk image using commands from the NanoServerImageGenerator module. Many of the parameters from this command will be passed to the underlying New-NanoServerImage function.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the new Nano server.
The initial Administrator password. You can change this later.
The IPv4 address for the new Nano server image. There is no validation in this command that the address is correct or available.
The path to the psd1 file with additional configuration information.
You can automate the process more efficiently with a ConfigData file. In fact, this is a required parameter. The psd1 file that might look like this:

@{ BasePath = "D:\2016Media\NanoServer" Edition = "standard" DeploymentType = "Guest" InterfaceNameorIndex = "Ethernet" EnableEMS = $True EnableRemoteManagementPort = $True ipV4DNS = "172.16.30.203" IPv4Subnet = "255.255.0.0" IPv4Gateway = "172.16.10.254" EMSPort = 1 EMSBaudRate = 115200 Defender = $True Clustering = $false Storage = $False Containers = $False Compute = $False Package = @('Microsoft-NanoServer-Guest-Package','Microsoft-NanoServer-DSC-Package') }
You can use this to set common and default values for your environment. Keys can be any parameter from New-NanoServerImage that isn't specified as a parameter in the New-MyNanoImage function.
The BasePath setting is the folder with the Nanoserver.wim and the Packages folder. The Diskpath setting is where to create the VHDX file. DeploymentType and Edition are also required.
Depending on your configuration you might want to add: MaxSize ServicePackages UnattendPath Development
With a configuration file you can create settings for different types of Nano installations such as DNS or Containers.
A sample file (nanodefaults.psd1) is included in the module directory.
The directory for the new file. The disk file will be constructed from the computer name. You only need to specify the DiskPath like D:\VMDisks.
Specifies an array of commands to run after setup completes.
Files to be copied to the root of C: in the new Nano server image.
The name of an Active Directory domain to join.
The path to a saved domain blob for an offline domain join.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If joining a domain and a matching AD Computer account already exists, then use it instead of the domain blob.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
The name of the new Nano server.
The path to the psd1 file with additional configuration information.
You can automate the process more efficiently with a ConfigData file. In fact, this is a required parameter. The psd1 file that might look like this:

@{ BasePath = "D:\2016Media\NanoServer" Edition = "standard" DeploymentType = "Guest" InterfaceNameorIndex = "Ethernet" EnableEMS = $True EnableRemoteManagementPort = $True ipV4DNS = "172.16.30.203" IPv4Subnet = "255.255.0.0" IPv4Gateway = "172.16.10.254" EMSPort = 1 EMSBaudRate = 115200 Defender = $True Clustering = $false Storage = $False Containers = $False Compute = $False Package = @('Microsoft-NanoServer-Guest-Package','Microsoft-NanoServer-DSC-Package') }
You can use this to set common and default values for your environment. Keys can be any parameter from New-NanoServerImage that isn't specified as a parameter in the New-MyNanoImage function.
The BasePath setting is the folder with the Nanoserver.wim and the Packages folder. The Diskpath setting is where to create the VHDX file. DeploymentType and Edition are also required.
Depending on your configuration you might want to add: MaxSize ServicePackages UnattendPath Development
With a configuration file you can create settings for different types of Nano installations such as DNS or Containers.
A sample file (nanodefaults.psd1) is included in the module directory.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Files to be copied to the root of C: in the new Nano server image.
The directory for the new file. The disk file will be constructed from the computer name. You only need to specify the DiskPath like D:\VMDisks.
The path to a saved domain blob for an offline domain join.
The name of an Active Directory domain to join.
The IPv4 address for the new Nano server image. There is no validation in this command that the address is correct or available.
The initial Administrator password. You can change this later.
If joining a domain and a matching AD Computer account already exists, then use it instead of the domain blob.
Specifies an array of commands to run after setup completes.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a Nano server image called NFoo with the given IP address that will belong to the Globomantics domain. An AD computer account for NFoo has already been created. The disk file will be created at E:\VMDisks\Nfoo.vhdx using additional settings from the NanoDefaults.psd1 file.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new Nano server virtual machine.
Use this command to create a new Nano Server Hyper-V virtual machine. It is assumed that you have already created the Nano server disk image file.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name for the new virtual machine. Typically this will be the same as the Nano computername.
The path to the VHDX pile
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicated whether you want the virtual machine to use Dynamic or Static memory.
This will be ignored if using Static memory setting.
The path where the new virtual machine configuration will be stored. You could use your Hyper-V default location but you would need to explicitly specify it: (get-vmhost).VirtualHardDiskPath
The number of processors for the new virtual machine.
Start the virtual machine after configuration.
The name of a Hyper-V switch to connect the virtual machine.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicated whether you want the virtual machine to use Dynamic or Static memory.
This will be ignored if using Static memory setting.
The name for the new virtual machine. Typically this will be the same as the Nano computername.
The path where the new virtual machine configuration will be stored. You could use your Hyper-V default location but you would need to explicitly specify it: (get-vmhost).VirtualHardDiskPath
The number of processors for the new virtual machine.
Start the virtual machine after configuration.
The name of a Hyper-V switch to connect the virtual machine.
The path to the VHDX pile
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-MyNanoVM -name Nfoo -vhdpath e:\vmdisks\nfoo.vhdx -processorcount 2 -switchname Lab

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new virtual machine called Nfoo using the specified vhdx file. The VM will be configured with default memory settings, 2 processors and assigned to the Lab virtual switch.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $imgparam = @{ ComputerName = "N-SRV1" Plaintext = "P@ssw0rd" IPv4Address = "172.16.40.2" DiskPath = "E:\VMdisks" ConfigData = ".\nanoFile.psd1" DomainName = "globomantics" ReuseDomainNode = $True } PS C:\> $vmparam = @{ Path = "E:\VMs" SwitchName = "DomainNet" MemoryStartupBytes = 1GB start = $True } PS C:\> New-MyNanoImage @imgparam | New-MyNanoVM @vmparam

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new virtual image and pipe the output to New-MyNanoVM using the specified parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the virtual machine time zone to match the Hyper-V host.
Set the time zone for the Nano server, or any computer, to that of the local host which is presumably the Hyper-V host. This command uses PowerShell remoting to make the change.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the name of a Nano server to update
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential for the remote server connection.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter the name of a Nano server to update
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential for the remote server connection.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-Matchingtimezone N-SRV8.globomantics.local -credential globomantics\administrator
PSComputerName Id -------------- -- N-SRV8.globomantics.local Eastern Standard Time

maml:description.maml:para: Test if a computer is a Nano server installation.
Test if a given computer is a Nano server installation.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a computer name to test
An alternate credential for the remote server connection.
Suppress normal output and return either True or False.
Enter a computer name to test
An alternate credential for the remote server connection.
Suppress normal output and return either True or False.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> test-isnanoserver chi-dc04,chi-p50,chi-nweb
Computername Caption OperatingSystemSKU IsNano ------------ ------- ------------------ ------ CHI-DC04 Microsoft Windows Server 2012 Datacenter 8 False CHI-P50 Microsoft Windows Server 2016 Datacenter 8 False CHI-NWEB Microsoft Windows Server 2016 Standard 144 True

dev:remarks.maml:para: Filter a list of computer names to get only Nano servers.

maml:description.maml:para: Get Windows updates on a Nano server installation.
Get and install Windows updates for a Nano server. This command uses the CIM cmdlets.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the name of a Nano server to update
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential for the remote CIM connection.
Don't install any updates, list them only.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter the name of a Nano server to update
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential for the remote CIM connection.
Don't install any updates, list them only.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Update-MyNanoServer chi-nweb -ScanOnly
KBArticleID : KB4013418 Description : Install this update to resolve issues in Windows. For a complete listing of the issues that are included in this update, see the associated Microsoft Knowledge Base article for more information. After you install this item, you may have to restart your computer. MsrcSeverity : RevisionNumber : 200 Title : Update for Windows Server 2016 for x64-based Systems (KB4013418) UpdateID : 025c4f16-fea1-4ea9-91fd-32209b4d8998 PSComputerName : chi-nweb
KBArticleID : KB4015438 Description : Install this update to resolve issues in Windows. For a complete listing of the issues that are included in this update, see the associated Microsoft Knowledge Base article for more information. After you install this item, you may have to restart your computer. MsrcSeverity : RevisionNumber : 200 Title : Cumulative Update for Windows Server 2016 for x64-based Systems (KB4015438) UpdateID : a69e4d69-0a50-4e79-a814-4b809d392071 PSComputerName : chi-nweb

dev:remarks.maml:para: Scan the specified computer for available updates but don't install the.
